data.title: old regenerative receiver, amazing performance
data.text:
arne thormodsen

Post by DumpsterDiver

From the photos it looks like it might be using either a UV-201 or a

UV-201A tube. In either case, that's a pretty valuable tube for

everyday use. If it's a "rainbow" tube,it's even more valuable.

You

Post by DumpsterDiver

might want to switch to a more common version of the 01A tube ...

likely perform even better too. If it's a UV-201, you'll also get much

more life from your "A" batteries if you swap it for a common 01A.

DD

I haven't done much research, in fact I haven't done anything with

tubes at all for about 25 years. I learned just enough from the

internet to not burn up the filaments when I first lit up the tubes,

and that the B voltage should be around 45 V. Also that because they

had brass bottoms and little nipples on top they were pretty old.

There are some numbers barely visible on the tubes, maybe I can work

them out.

One pulls about 0.25A at 5 volts. It's partially metallized inside

(Mg getter?), with a bit of a rainbow effect. Is this what you mean?

The other tube pulls near 1A at 5 volts. It's pretty much just clear

glass.

Both tubes work, but the one that pulls 0.25A is considerably more

sensitive. It's the one I pulled in the UT station with.

I'm treating them very nicely, in case you are wondering. They get

packed up in soft material and put back in a metal container when I'm

not using them. I figured authentic replacements would set me back a

pretty penny.

Actually I may try to get it to work with a FET if I can. I've seen

some circuits I might be able to adapt without changing much of the

wiring in the radio.

--arne
